executive_summary: The data privacy policy shows a foundational understanding of GDPR, particularly regarding lawful processing. However, it is critically deficient in addressing the data subject's 'Right to Erasure' (Article 17), posing a high financial risk for EU operations.

compliance_breakdown.clause_text: Personal data must be processed lawfully, fairly and transparently.
compliance_breakdown.evidence_in_policy: We are committed to processing all personal data lawfully and will clearly inform individuals about how their data is used.
compliance_breakdown.recommendation: This is a good start. To be fully compliant, explicitly state the lawful bases you rely on (e.g., 'Consent', 'Legitimate Interest') for different processing activities.

potential_penalties.details: Fines up to â‚¬20 million or 4% of global turnover.

compliance_breakdown.clause_text: Data subjects have the right to request erasure of their personal data.
compliance_breakdown.evidence_in_policy: We retain user data for a period of seven years for our records.
compliance_breakdown.recommendation: Major Risk: This policy contradicts the 'Right to be Forgotten.' You must implement a process for handling data erasure requests and update this policy to state that users can request deletion of their data, subject to legal retention obligations.

potential_penalties.details: Complaints to EU data protection authorities.
